reviewText:
`Their lives became a living hell...when past, present and future collided!'  That's the tagline used on the DVD case for The Day Time Ended aka Earth's Final Fury aka Vortex aka Time Warp (1980).  I knew how they felt for 90 minutes, watching this film (the DVD case states approximately 90 minutes, but it was more like 70 to 75 minutes)...okay, maybe it wasn't that bad, but you'd think a film credited with four writers could at least have made sense...rarely have I seen a film so lacking in direction or plot...directed by John `Bud' Cardos (Kingdom of the Spiders, Outlaw of Gor), the film stars Jim Davis (you may remember him as Jock Ewing on TV's Dallas), Dorothy Malone (Peyton Place), Natasha Ryan (Kingdom of the Spiders, The Amityville Horror), Marcy Lafferty, who was once married to William Shatner, both of whom appeared in 1977's Kingdom of the Spiders, along with the above mentioned Ryan, Scott C. Kolden (Sigmund and the Sea Monsters), and Christopher Mitchum (American Commandos, Magic Kid), son of actor Robert Mitchum (I'll saw one thing about Chris is that looking at his credits of low budget, schlocky B films, it doesn't look like he relied on nepotism to get good roles).

The film opens with a shot of outer space, and voice over I couldn't hear because of the accompanying music (poor sound editing), and also the sound quality on this DVD was very shoddy.  This goes on for like three minutes, and the gist of it is there's a cosmic phenomena, three super novas colliding at once, and now, some many years later, the effects are reaching the planet Earth...the bulk of the film takes place in some southwestern desert, where patriarch Grant (Davis) has built a solar powered home (looking much like Uncle Owen and Aunt Beru's funky little domicile on Tantooine in the film Star Wars, only not as good), away from all the hustle and bustle.  Next we witness Grant and his son-in-law Richard (Mitchum) picking up the rest of the family at the airport, including Grant's wife Ana (Malone), Grant's daughter and Richard's wife Beth (Lafferty), the granddaughter Jenny (Ryan), and Grant's son Steve (Kolden).  The group returns to the ranch, and soon strange things begin happening in the form of strange green lights inside the house, light switches not working, furniture in disarray, etc.  Also, they begin witnessing lights in the night sky, and even the occasion UFO zipping by...during the night even stranger phenomena begin occurring in the form of really bad CGI and even worse stop motion effects of hostile, misshapen creatures fighting each other in the corral, outside the house.  Apparently the effects of the trinary supernova have torn a new one in the time/space continuum, effectively creating a localized vortex on Grant's property (at least that's what I could get, as the film wasn't as forthcoming as it should have been).  What's an isolationist family to do?  I suppose when the fickle forces of nature give you cosmic lemons, you make cosmic lemonade...

I suppose my biggest complaint with this film was its' confusing, muddled, and utterly pointless plot.  It actually took an hour before the audience was let in on what was going on (this was done by the unceremonious dumping of a small but steaming pile of exposition on the audience, as Davis' character, the rural rancher, becomes Mr. Physics during an epiphanic moment when he realizes `we're in a time warp, a vortex, if you will'...later we're treated to a much larger pile as the daughter, who got sucked into the vortex, and later returns relating about as much lameness as I could stand)...prior to that, we were treated to a series of odd (mostly stupid), unrelated events that never really lead anywhere, or had much purpose.  I did get the impression there may have been a good, original concept here, but it was obliterated within the execution.  The special effects are about as good as one might expect within a low budget feature as this, the main bulk of it being stop motion effects with creatures looking much like those (only not as good) from scene in Star Wars, on the Millennium Falcon, where the characters were playing a chess-like game, and minor effects featuring obvious CGI/blue screen work.  The direction was pretty awful, especially noticeable during the scenes where the characters were supposed to react to special effects to be added later.  I could almost imagine how it went... `Okay, now act shocked and scared, as that empty space will be occupied by a horrible monster once we insert it during post production'...'okay, I was going for shocked and scared, not perplexed and moronic'.  The acting was pretty shoddy, but then I would be more inclined to blame this on the script and the director, as the talent was probably as confused as I was with regards to what was supposed to be going on in the film.  Also, I thought the ending to be sort of a cop out.

The quality of the full screen, pan and scan print on this DVD isn't great, but I've seen worse.  The real problem lies within the craptacular transfer.  The picture has a stuttering, jittery quality that occurs anytime there's movement on the screen.  I've never witnessed this particular problem before, but it's incredibly annoying, and lasts through nearly the entire film.  The audio's poor, and my player indicates it's PCM 48Khz.  There are a couple of extras featuring a montage of trailers for this film, and three more including Laserblast (1978), Creepozoids (1987), and End of the World (1977), along with some Full Moon Entertainment promotional materials.  Is this film a cult classic?  I'd say more of an oddity...if you're looking for a real cult classic, check out Don Johnson in A Boy and His Dog (1975).  Another thing, the DVD case listed this as being rated R, but that's obviously a mistake...PG would be more applicable.

Cookieman108

The quality of this DVD is worse than my orignal 10 year old VHS tape. Movement of characters across the screen is jerky, sound is PCM 48Khz 16bit sick stereo (dialogue on left channel, music on right). Picture format is 4:3 Fullframe.

You might almost think you were watching a Pirate / Bootleg copy it is SO BAD!

I've always loved this movie and have it on a DVD by Brentwood but i wanted a better copy so i bought this- the print looks about the same (and like my brentwood DVD not in widescreen)and the soundtrack seems to be in stereo but the DVD transfer BLOWS! it has odd vert lines on any movement VERY ANNOYING! wait for a better DVD ver or get a vhs copy.  This is going back.

I first saw this movie on TV in the 80s and for some reason it stuck in my mind. Now having seen it again i'm not too sure why, although if you take into account the low budget and date that it was made i suppose it isn't too bad. Its basically a strange mix of UFOs, Aliens and 'Monsters' which terrorise a family on a ranch.. The ending is a little bizarre but overall  quite an enjoyable movie.

I first saw this movie in a local video store I decieded to pick up a copy of it. It was just the way I thought it would be. bad acting, ok special effects, desent low-budget plot, etc.
 if you like prehistoric monsters, lasers, or sci-fi movies, this is for you.

Even though it is clearly made on a very low budget, I honorably disagree with the previous reviewer that THE DAY TIME ENDED is out-and-out junk.  Far worse sci-fi films than this have been made on budgets fifty to a hundred times what it cost to make this film.
The story involves a family (led by Jim Davis, Chris Mitchum, and Dorothy Malone) who have moved out to a solar-powered home in the Mojave Desert to escape the terrors of big-city crime in Los Angeles.  When they get to their isolated home, however, they discover that it has been trashed.  Initially, it is thought that motorcycle vandals were the cause.  In fact, however, it is the result of a trinary supernova explosion that occurred two hundred years ago and whose effects are only being felt on Earth now.  Alien beings and their accompanying UFO spacecraft have pulled the family and their house into a mysterious time/space warp, full of weird and sometimes terrifying phonomena.  The coda finds the family venturing across the desert plains to a beautiful futuristic crystal city, with Davis intoning, "Maybe this was all meant to be."
John 'Bud' Cardos, who directed the fine 1977 low-budget horror film KINGDOM OF THE SPIDERS, has set himself a very ambitious task to make a good sci-fi film on a very slim budget.  This film's inspirations are clearly Kubrick's 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY and Spielberg's CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND; and while the special effects are, unsurprisingly, not up to the standards of those two masterful movies, I think they hold up pretty well.  The stop-motion dinosaurs and monsters are fairly well done, as are the UFOs and the trinary nova explosions. Most fascinating for me was the eerie green pyramid that the family's youngest daughter (Natasha Ryan) sees, which may have been inspired by Arthur C. Clarke's short story "The Sentinel" (which provided part of the inspiration for 2001).
THE DAY TIME ENDED may not qualify as a sci-fi masterpiece, but it certainly deserves to be rediscovered at the very least as a minor sci-fi gem.  One can do far worse than this low-budget film that occasionally looks like a glossy big-budget venture.

I remember, twenty or so years ago, when the television commercials for this film looked pretty cool.  My friends and I had planned on seeing it, but it left the theaters after the first week it was released.  I now know  why.
A threadbare story is coupled with a few idiotic characters that  seem to have been snatched from several different P.M. soaps.  Throw in a  little girl who talks to inanimate objects, add a freestyle rubber monster  wrestling match, sprinkle with a tiny alien gray that seems to have no  relevance to an already irrelevant story...
Shake well...
Let it all  run around a movie set while you film it...viola!  We'll call it "The  Day Time Ended"!
Best line from this film: "Have you seen my  pony?"
I don't know what it is about this movie, but I can't tear my self away from it as it has great stop motion animation as well as great aliens.

I originally saw bits and pieces of this movie on TV. The memorable element being a device that can absorb kinetic energy and stop and disintegrate flying bullets in midair. The second most influential sci-fi movie for me after Forbidden Planet. Pros: It's in color; more techy than I remember; regardless of what anyone else says, the quality is excellent. Cons: Duration,... too short. I've spent years looking for this, and am really pleased I took the chance on this one.
Slightly enjoyable Sci-fi movie.  This was not the best period for many movies of the genre. If you like Sci-fi, then it will be worth the experience.

good premise destroyed by whatever passed for a script, Jim Davis and Dorothy Malone were both good actors  in their day clearly dragged out of retirement presumably for money and they probably had no idea just how bad this was. Chris Mitchum was in a few B grade movies but was never in the class of his father and mercifully did not act in many more movies. So much for the cast.
The movie is disjointed, implausible, impossible to follow, the idea of a family being saved from a cataclysm to take up life in a later time line is an interesting sci fi plot but this treatment of the idea is a disaster. It is a little like Noah trying to save his family without the flood,or ark,  no suggestion of what the cataclysm to befall the earth really is or why they are being spared from it.
The producers should have saved the money till they had a movie worthwhile to invest in, this movie is a DUD or if you like a BOMB. Not worth buying or viewing, plenty of better movies out there if you like 50s/60s kitch to invest in.

I love "B" movies especially science fiction. This was probably one the worst movies I've ever seen. I cant even think it would be worth buying even for the camp value. Like I said I love B movies and campy sci fi movies.

This may be the best ever to come out of Hollywood. In the league with such masterpieces as Metropolis,King Kong,Forbidden Planet,and yes even Star Wars. The plot is something untried in Hollywood history,and yet The Producer...I forget,well he makes it work. Buy yours today,as soon as they catch on? you won't find em.for 3 bucks anymore.

this movie  is different not like others and it a cool house out in the desert and the male actor I don't remember him in much movies and its kinda slow but has special effects really good for the time and it not a bloody kill up stuff but a family getting caught up in time travel with weird creatures. I love time travel movies,  I also know its possible  to do it .
Lots of action , drama, excitement, great characters, and plots, I'd recommend this movie, to anyone looking for someone who enjoys cliff hangers.
It's about a family whose house gets "caught" in a dimensional warp. Their front yard becomes another planet, it seems.

The introduction of this movie is a picture of space with a voiceover talking about linear time and how the narrator now knew that time was not linear, or something like that.  The film then focuses on a family moving to the desert in southern California.  You know we are in trouble when the youngest member of the family, a little girl (Natasha Ryan, who had numerous roles as a child), sees a glowing pyramid thingy back behind the barn.

All sorts of interesting things happen after the little girl discovers the glowing pyramid thingy.  The little girl's pony disappears, and then it reappears.  A little stop-motion alien-looking person appears in the little girl's room and does some things that verge on being magical.  Then some sort of spacecraft appears that the little girl says is evil.  The flying craft did try to burn a hole in the girl's closet door, which seems fairly evil.

The family appears to be at the center of some sort of phenomena associated with the explosion of three stars several hundred years in the past.  The patriarch of the family, Grant Williams, played by the late Jim Davis in one of his final acting roles, eventually tells us that we are in a time space warp, which is evidenced by the appearance of stuff from the future and the past, including a couple of rather large, vaguely reptilian creatures.

The movie is laden with special effects from beginning to end, which run the gamut from what appear to be spaceships, to creatures, and even a futuristic city.  I normally dislike movies that rely too heavily on special effects, because the special effects often serve as a crutch for an awful plot and for awful acting.  In the case of this movie, the special effects are the focus of the film, and the family has the unfortunate luck to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.  The point of the movie is how the family reacts to being at the center of celestial events that transcend space and time.

This independent science fiction movie includes the great Dorothy Malone (who has won multiple awards, including an Oscar for best supporting actress for "Written on the Wind") and Christopher Mitchum.  Marcy Lafferty, who was once married to William Shatner and appeared in "Star Trek: The Motion Picture," was nominated for a Saturn Award for best supporting actress in this movie, losing out to Veronica Cartwright in "Alien."

Science fiction films were evolving rapidly in the late 1970's and the early 1980's.  Movies such as "Alien," "Star Wars," "Star Trek: The Motion Picture," "Superman," "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," and many others were re-defining science fiction and fantasy.  The films of the era included a mixture of B movies and groundbreaking films as studios sought a formula that would draw audiences.  While this movie falls well short of the great films of the era, the film has some charm to it, and the special effects were quite good given the technological limitations of the era and the budget of the film.

I have seen some criticism of the ending, with some people calling the ending strange.  I think the ending was consistent with the tenor of the film.  The point of the movie was surviving the space-time warp, so the ending was merely to indicate that the family had a potential future that did not involve being eaten by a large, reptilian creature.  The ending is consistent with some other films of the era, and many newer films, where the ending contains a level of ambiguity.  However, the ending of the movie was not the point in this case; it was all about the journey.

A much bigger problem with this film is the quality of the film itself.  The film has entered the public domain, and sadly, many of these films suffer once they are no longer under copyright.  Anyone can copy the film onto a DVD and sell it, and because the no-name companies that provide these copies come and go, you can never figure out who has the best copy.  My copy was hardly great, though not awful.  My only suggestion is to read the reviews and try to figure out which company seems to be offering the best version.

I liked this low-budget film.  The special effects were fun, the actors generally did okay with the material they had.  Yes, there were moments of corniness and strange script lines, which tends to happen in low-budget films, but when you look past the weaknesses, you have a movie fine for a bowl of popcorn and a quiet Saturday evening.

Enjoy!

A family decides to build a solar home in the Southern California desert, right in UFO alley during a triple super nova of some distant stars. This causes a visitation by space aliens who transfer their home through time and space at will to the planet of Claymation. The film is transferred poorly to DVD. Just about everything about the film was horrid from the acting to the script to the special effects to the science.

The film has gained cult status, why, I do not know. To me it is just a bad Gumby film. It is more suited for children, although they let loose a GD early in the feature. There are better cult films out there with better characters.

a must have.. if you have enjoyed Laser-Blast and EQuinox..this one fits right in there..good retro-powered flic..Quercky and fun..the Stop-motion has a acouple cool scenes..a few live action shots are pretty interesting..I Like it Beacause it's Retro-Powered..Latittude-Zero will give you afew chuckles also..with Cesar Romero (Joker from 60's Batman tv series show) also playing a Bad Guy in that flic..and i think the Guy that played in the Green Slime is also in it..enjoy.. and remember life is only worth living..in if it is an endless eternity of Saturday morning cartoons (and live action tv shows) I smell the..Popcorn?? Retro-Power Rules..another great flic is infra! Infra!!"Infra-Man!!" and whats the hold up (Asian Masters) with my Godzilla vs Gamera movie??What gives??? wer're running out of time..will they still be able to stop beaten the crap out of each other..long enough to team up and save the earth??

Kooky science fiction with an abstract, dreamlike approach!  This movie is really entertaining, considering it is almost totally confusing!  The story, such as it is:  A family is having a get-together out at the grandparents' cool solar-powered house isolated way out in the desert.  On the radio is news of a "trinary supernova" (that really happened hundreds of years ago) sending waves of energy across the galaxy.  At some point in mid-barbecue, the family is shocked to see reality fold in upon itself, and they find themselves accosted by storms of lights, flying intelligent vacuum cleaners, giant monsters, and other completely inexplicable things.  At the end, they come to the realization that their entire world has changed, and that there is no way back to their previous life; they now have a new appreciation for how wonderful and awe-inspiring reality really is.

I know people tend to criticize this movie, and with good reason, in a sense.  Because it makes no sense; a bunch of effects sequences and no really clear plot or resolution.  Can you imagine being one of the actors in this film...reacting to various and sundry visual effects that were to be added later, gawking, gaping, acting startled or amazed or surprised.  At least in a typical Ray Harryhausen film, the effects were part of a more or less clearly defined story and that would help the actors get their emotional reactions correct.  In this film, the actors have no such anchor, as they react to "yet another weird thing" happening, and another, and so on.  Just watch 'em...they are doing a tough job.

After a number of weird encounters with giant monsters, flying vacuum cleaners, and storms of sparkly lights, the grandfather (played by Jim Davis) comes to the conclusion, "You know what this is? It's a time-space warp!" and the grandson says, "Uh...I don't know exactly what that is..."  And, frankly, neither do we, the audience, but we are stuck in this film just as the characters are.

After being separated, everyone is brought back together and the mom (played by Marcy Lafferty) explains, "I FELT a series of IMAGES," and they all walk off towards a "city of light" that somehow reminds me of the shimmering Emerald City in "The Wizard of Oz."  The credits roll.  What a strange film!  You can actually fall asleep several times while watching it, and when you wake up, you won't have missed anything important to the plot, because there ain't no plot, to speak of.  Awesome!

Well, heck! The first time a person sees this film, it should be immediately understood that nothing that happens is ever really explained, nor is there any ATTEMPT to explain it.  The film just plain isn't interested in pesky details like that!  As soon as the viewer forgets about looking for the story, this very odd film can become very enjoyable.  See it today--pop yourself some popcorn and just see the darn thing.  It's a lot of fun.

I remember when I first saw this movie. it was during Chrismas break and I didn't have anywhere to go on a snowy night. I turned on the tv and presto, The Day Time ended. It entertained me and got me hooked into watching stop action animation once again. CG is nice, but it isn't the same as SAA. The story is kind of bare, but good enough to show off the creatures and the main actors. They do great stuff with the limited material.
this is a fun Saturday afternoon special.

I saw this movie at a drive-in theater back in the early 1980's.  I have the VHS tape of this movie and have watched it 3 or 4 times over the years. Some of the special effects are very good and some are really bad (weird-looking monsters, miniature aliens, UFO's, and crazy noises along with what looks like "4th of July sparklers" flying through the air).  There is a scene where the husband & wife are taking a leisurely stroll through the desert at night. Suddenly, some lights start coming toward them.  Then 2 UFOs fly directly over their heads within 20 feet or so.  That scene only last about 15 seconds, but it's the best scene in the movie.  The plot is pretty silly and the ending is just plain dumb.  I guess you could say that this movie is so bad....it's good.  If you like to watch science fiction, it's worth a look.
thisis just a four star  but its about some actors in the past and the style of making it was different than most  its worth the money, unless your a special effects after year 2000 person

I love this movie, man.  Family owns an awesome house in the desert that the old man built. KUDOs to the old dude for building such a far out house!  They think bikers messed with it.. But no, weird stuff is happening man.  A mirror fixes itself, water turns on and off via thought.  The little girl has a new imaginary friend out behind the barn, a green glowing Mayan temple looking thing!  Thank God for such things!  The family has an outstanding outdoor barbecue!  I got hungry just watching them pass that mouth watering food around!  Yes, loved it.  The son in law goes to town to do some business, pops open a beer and sips it kinda weird, gonna have to try that myself.  A storm hits.  He heads back home. Meanwhile all kinds of weird stuff is going on... end of the world kinda stuff.  Suddenly their front yard turns into a parking lot for lost otherworldly vehicles, I spotted many interesting craft, freeze frame and see what you can spot!  Cool hovercrafts and massive aircraft, hey, I think the Bermuda Triangle just got dumped on their lawn!  A huge creature attacks, time is passing at a different speed out in the barn than it is back in the house... Very cool, I've experienced this phenomena myself, always cool when that happens!  I thank God for moments like that!  When all looks lost, the little girl and her mother get sucked into the Vortex!  JENNY!  JENNY! Stay outta tha V O R TEX!  OH NO, she was gone with her mother Beth following close behind, now what..  What we have here is a Time Space Warp.. Suddenly the entire family is transported to Heaven!  Yes I'm quite sure that's where they end up.  The new Jerusalem can be seen in the distance.  Holy Angels in flying saucers zoom around.  Hey look!  There's their daughter!  She's been transformed by the Love of God!  There's Jenny, and there's her father! Hey!  Everybody is safe and sound as they walk toward Heaven! All is well, all is as it is meant to be!  Thanks God!  I thank you God for such a wonderful movie.  I love this movie, man.  Thanks God!  (Spoken while pointing both index fingers toward the Heavens!)

I remember this movie from my childhood. I remember the mild panic it evoked in me.
For it's time It was perhaps not as slick as it could've been. But It had a great concept. The story itself could be due for a remake. not unlike so many other RE-makes out there. But with a faster pace and updated effects this is a good story.
All in all I found it to be entertaining. If a little cheesy by today's standards.
But I am a lover of b and c rate Sci-fi.
I believe most film critiques are afraid to admit they like something their peers or readers may perceive to be unworthy of praise , so they say the meanest things about the subject film. Not me. I do my best to suspend dissbelief for two hours and enjoy the story. Not try to pick it to pieces.
For example I found the old 80's film Megaforce to be a live action version of another faveorite "G.I. Joe." I enjoy this little nugget of cheese on a regular basis. I Have a special binnder full of dvd's called my "CHEESE TRAY".
Also another lamb basted film I found truely entertaining was Eddie Murphy's
The Adventures of Pluto Nash. It hit all the right buttons with me. It is widely concidered a box office flop. And has received the worst reviews. Thats nice...
If it makes the critic feel good about themselves. I loved it.

I remember seeing this as a co-feature in 1980 or '81.
It was kitschy good fun, and worth owning if only to hear Jim Davis
drawl out "We must be in some kinda time-space wooorp!"

The disappointment came when major segments of the first half or so of this film was practically unwatchable due to the herky-jerky motions that evidenced not a poor DVD transfer, but a Horrible one!
It brought to mind images of RCA connectors strung from an old VHS ("Beta"??) player to the inputs of a 386 PC.

Whoever OK'd the release of this shoddy mess should be placed in some kinda time-space wooorp!

I found this movie on Amazon after searching for it in several places. bought this DVD mainly to rekindle my childhood fascination which I caught a glimpse of its trailer as a kid but didn't have the money to watch back then. Until now.  Didnt really think the movie really lived up to the thrill / fascination & curiosity I had for it as a kid. Some parts were still cool as I anticipated, sufficient suspense albeit extremely dated special effects (eg.like house invasion scene) but classic.

Major disappointment was the way the story chose to end.

I have always liked this film but have avoided purchasing this stand alone DVD due to reviews here about the quality. I just purchased a 2 DVD/4 movie box called TIME TRAVELERS put out by Brentwood which has THE DAY TIME ENDED on it...and the transfer/audio/color and picture all look great to me,at least as good as my VHS copy...maybe even better. If you're a fan of the film seek out this boxset if the single DVD release isn't up to par.

BUYER BEWARE!:  This film was shot in the 2:35 widescreen aspect ratio, but this zero grade DVD is presented in a horrible squarebox format.  Unwatchable from the first frame and a complete waste of money.  Shame on Full Moon, though I should have expected no less.

This piece of crap is horrible. It's included in the "Sci-Fi Invasion" 50 movie pack. I don't think I was able to watch more than 5 or 6 minutes of it. I Absolutely love Science Fiction - but this movie is just plain awful.
great no-budget drive-in movie
It was okay

Id really love to get a good copy of this classic.  This captured my young imagine when it aired on Saturday afternoon Monster Rally or whatever.  Stop-motion animation and other practical matte effects were put to good use despite an obviously small budget.  Inventive, creative, a little creepy (but safe for kids), and a little tense this film delivered the goods.  (Note: most copies of this movie I've come across are of poor quality.)

Three generations of Williams are meeting up at grandpas (a recognizable Jim Davis) ranch out in the desert.  But theres some funny atmospherics going on, lights in the sky zip zooming about, and wild abrupt weather changes.  Not all that concerned the family goes about their business until the youngest wakes up to an alien sprite that glows and dances through the air; its like a malnourished troll without all the fuzzy hair.  This small, fanciful being is helpful and alerts the family to an ominous floating silver ship about the size and look of a vacuum cleaner but with double-pivot metal arms.  This thing slowly hovers through the house burning doors and zapping pictures and creating fires.  But thats not all.  Alien monsters appear and do battle in the Williams backyard and the time storms keep getting worse and worse.  Its all fairly effective in creating a mild sense of tension and curiosity.  This isn't any Close Encounters of the Third Kind epic but its modest scope is enhanced by actors who play their roles straight which helps sell the unsettling shenanigans.  The modest spfx, including some scratchy but fun stop-motion work, certainly feel dated and a little strained but their clever uses convey an obvious love by the filmmakers for their craft.
It's an OK B movie from yesteryear but not in the class of THEM or This Island Earth
what can i say , this movie sucks. Plain and simple
A lot of special effects , very little plot. A good movie for kids  ;sort of like "Land of the Lost."
the stop motion was good , the story was so-so and the quality was average.
I finally purchased this movie, I seen it when I was a kid and have been looking for it for a long time.
